Intro to Python
Want to code? Begin with Python! Developed and released in 1991, Python is a popular beginner-friendly high-level programming language. Below is a little peek into this popular programming language to get started with:

History

Python was first created by Guido van Rossum in early 1991. The main motivation behind building this awesome language was originally to solve some of the problems that the programmers were facing in earlier programming languages like ABC Programming Language. Since Rossum himself had helped create ABC Programming Language earlier in his career, he knew the flaws and wanted to fix them. In the process, Python was born that made it a lot easier for people to read and write codes in addition to resolving the earlier issues in ABC.

Python allows you to write the same program in a lot fewer lines of code than other programming languages like Java and C++. Since it is a high-level programming language, the code is mostly similar to English and can be easily read, written and understood. This very fact makes it a very beginner-friendly language.

Python is an object oriented programming language (OOP) but also supports functional programming. If you want to understand OOP and functional programming paradigms, the blog I have linked here explains it in depth. In CS111, you would be writing many functions in Python. This W3School's online resource about Python functions is good material to go through if you want to learn more. A simple Python function that takes two numbers from the user, adds them and prints the sum can look like this: 

def printSum(num1,num2):
    sum = num1 + num2
    print("The sum is:", sum)

If you want to use the above function, you simply call it with the numbers you want to add. For example: if you call printSum(5, 6), the result you would see on the screen is ‚ÄúThe sum is: 11‚Äù.

You can also import and use many functionalities that Python already has for you. They are called libraries. You can learn more about different libraries from this Python documentation linked here.¬† You can import any specific library and use its functions in your program depending on your needs.

You can then add s1 to a list of other student objects or create methods to run in the student class.

So‚Ä¶What Wellesley Courses use Python?

  • CS 111: Computer Programming and Problem Solving
  • CS 231: Fundamental Algorithms (just a tiny bit)

Best *IDEs* for this language üéâ

  • Thonny - Thonny gives you all the simplicity of an environment you need for beginning your programming journey with Python. It is easy to install, and its coding and debugging tools make programming more intuitive.
  • PyCharm - Created by JetBrains, PyCharm is suitable for all skill levels, from beginners to professional developers. It has an open-source, free Community edition and also a paid Professional edition.
  • IDLE - This IDE accompanies your installation of Python and allows you to write and execute the code like the other IDEs but with very limited features. It is usually used only for smaller programs with fewer lines of code.

Check out the TCS IDE page to explore many more IDEs in detail.

What can you build with Python?

Python is used to make tons of cool applications ranging from web development frameworks like Django and Flask to cool computer games like Disney Toontown Online. It has libraries from turtle (linked here) that allows you to create really appealing and fun visual graphics and animations to matplotlib (linked here) that offers complex data visualization tools and functionalities.

Check out this list from DataQuest where you can find some cool project ideas. Just as any other computational technology can be abused, Python can be misused to create unfair programs too. As you progress in your programming journey, it is always important to be aware of any potential negative impacts your programs could cause. If you are interested in learning more about this topic, I recommend you review the ACM Code of Ethics linked here for more detailed explanations.

Further resources

Want more learning resources? I got you!

The Python documentation linked here has everything you need to know, from beginner to advanced Python programming concepts, alongside examples to aid your understanding. While it is a good resource to refer to, it might not be the best in terms of your visual experience.

If you're looking for a more interactive and fun learning experience, W3Schools linked here is my strongest recommendation. It provides you with explanations of all your necessary Python concepts categorized by topic and also an integrated coding environment to practice each new concept you learn.

Geeks for Geeks linked here is another all-in-one-place resource for Python. It has detailed explanations for all concepts in Python. You can use this to learn about some important and widely used Python libraries while also finding how Python is used in different areas like Machine Learning, Data Analytics, and Artificial Intelligence.

Go ahead and start creating!

Happy learning,

Anjali Karki
